paths.title: Learning To Bake Sourdough Bread
paths.summary: My first attempt at creating a sourdough starter, then adding flour and baking it. One failed attempt at letting the bread rise, but I succeeded in the end.

paths.title: Learning To Make Pandan Cake
paths.summary: Trying out my mom's recipe for Pandan Cake.

paths.title: My First Attempt At Croissants
paths.summary: Making croissants, the perfect gift to bring to the office.

paths.title: Learning Data Science
paths.summary: I want to learn data science in half a year. Come follow my progress!

steps.title: Prepare the Starter
steps.content:
The first step is to prepare sourdough starter. I poured 3 tbsp. of mashed potato flakes, 3 tbsp. of sugar, 1 cup of water, and 2 1/4 tbsp. of yeast into a plastic cup and covered it in cling wrap. I plan to let the container sit on the counter for 5 days and stirred it for 5 minutes everyday.

![img](https://1.bp.blogspot.com/-TIz-GJjDFGI/TZqFpVYN8RI/AAAAAAAACi4/OHMszJqz1S8/s1600/images+%25282%2529.jpg)

steps.title: Continue Feeding the Starter
steps.content:
I fed my sourdough starter with another 3 tbsp. of potato flakes, 3/4 tbsp. of sugar, and 1 cup of water.

IMPORTANT! Over the past few days I did some more reading and learned that I have to avoid letting my starter come into contact with metal as much as possible. Sourdough bread is acidic, if I let my starter come into contact with metals there'll be a chemical reaction and my yeast will die.

steps.title: Take Some of Starter for Baking
steps.content:
At night I removed 1 cup of my sourdough starter to use for baking my sourdough bread.

I plan to rinse and repeat this process to continue baking sourdough bread with my starter.

steps.title: Add the Flour
steps.content:
Today I finally attempted to bake the bread itself. I mixed 1 cup of my starter with 1 1/2 cups of warm water, 1 1/2 tbsp. of salt, 1/2 cup of sugar, and 1/2 cup of vegetable oil in a large bowl. Afterwards I added 6 cups of flour and mixed it in. Then I lightly covered the dough in oil, covered it and left it to rise overnight.

I observed it after two hours and it seemed to be rising pretty well!

![img](https://sweetcayenne.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/05/sourdough-rising.jpg)

steps.title: Try Again (oops)
steps.content: Disaster! Today I woke up and checked on my bread the first thing in the morning. Unfortunately it completely collapsed. I consulted a sourdough forum online and found [a relevant thread](https://sourdough.com/forum/collapsed-dough). Apparently, letting it rise overnight is way too long at room temperature. So tonight when I tried again with another cup of starter, I let my sourdough rise in the refrigerator.

steps.title: Bake the Bread
steps.content:
Today I checked on my sourdough first thing in the morning again and it was looking good. So I proceeded to knead the dough for a few minutes. At first the dough stuck to my fingers while kneading, so I tried sprinkling some flour over my hands and it helped keep the dough smooth. Then I divided the dough into two pans.

I preheated the oven to over 350 degrees then placed the 2 pans of dough inside. I let it bake for 45 minutes until the bread became a nice light golden brown. And success!

![img](https://3.bp.blogspot.com/-eHuBK0FISEA/TZqC3KT745I/AAAAAAAACik/6qj8mKNbztA/s1600/DSCF6688.JPG)

steps.title: Success!
steps.content:
This was my first time baking sourdough, and I think it turned out pretty well. There were some lucky breaks like when I used a plastic container instead of a metal one, but I also had to retry the process when my sourdough collapsed overnight. All in all though, a good experience.

https://proxy.duckduckgo.com/iu/?u=http%3A%2F%2F2.bp.blogspot.com%2F-I_uPEYSGiZo%2FTZqC4Hkj4wI%2FAAAAAAAACiw%2Fl3Tbp1EwWro%2Fs1600%2FDSCF6728.JPG&f=1

steps.title: Online research into data science
steps.content:
### Useful articles:
- [Wikipedia on Data Science](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Data_science)
- [Michael Hochster's response on Quora](https://www.quora.com/What-is-data-science)
- [Coursera Crash Course](https://www.coursera.org/learn/data-science-course/lecture/X4Z9T/what-is-data-science)

### Summary:
I learnt that data science is about **analysis** and **prediction** on data.
And that a lot of curated datasets is freely available online to practice on!

steps.title: Plotting scatterplot with pyturtle
steps.content: Turned out to be a bad idea. 1/10 would not recommend. Apparently [matplotlib](https://google.com) is a better tool to plot data. Guess I'll have to learn that first...

steps.title: Data analysis
steps.content:
Thanks to Guan Lim's helpful [comment](), I have decided to learn matplotlib and numpy. I found this [tutorial from Gary Newman]() to be immensely helpful.

Here are the beautiful graphs I've plotted from the [housing prices dataset from UCLA]().
![](http://bigdata-madesimple.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/04/Relationship-between-RM-and-Price.png)

steps.title: Regression ??
steps.content:
Armed with matplotlib and numpy, I wanted to start analysing data.
The simplest analysis method according to [this blog post]() is linear regression.
But I have no idea what is linear regression.
Time for some math remedial...

steps.title: Statistics primer
steps.content: Thank god for Guan Tan and his detailed path "Statistics primer for data science"!

steps.title: Participate in Kaggle Competition
steps.content: I found this great website [Kaggle]() to practice my newfound data science skills on. I placed 103rd out of 120, but it was a good way to cement my understanding in data science and to learn from the pros out there. This marks the end of this phase of my data science journey. For those who had followed me thus far, do share your capstone projects in the comments here as well!
